clinical_study.brief_title: Interest of Ultrasound in the Diagnosis of Severity of Lateral Ankle Sprain
clinical_study.official_title: Interest of Ultrasound in the Diagnosis of Severity of Lateral Ankle Sprain

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

clinical_study.source: Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Saint Etienne

brief_summary.textblock: Ankle sprain is a frequent and widely trivialized trauma. Misdiagnosed or poorly treated, it can recur and thus develop into chronic ankle instability. It can be associated with complications which, if not detected early, can lead to long-term sequelae.

detailed_description.textblock:
The hypothesis of this study is that ultrasound can better characterize the severity stages of the sprain and can diagnose complications that may have gone unnoticed on physical examination.
Patients will be evaluated clinically : demographics, history, clinical examination, functional scores. Ultrasound and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) will be performed during the first month to determine the stage of severity and to look for complications. The main aim is to evaluate the interest of ultrasound in the diagnosis of the severity of lateral ankle sprain. The secondary purpose is to compare an ultrasound assessment of severity with clinical and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) assessment.

primary_outcome.description: Collected in medical record. This system utilises a classification that is based on injury severity related to the amount of tissue damage and associated functional loss. It categorises muscle injuries into three grades, ranging from grade 1 with no appreciable tissue tear, grade 2 with tissue damage and reduced strength of the musculotendinous unit and grade 3 with complete tear of musculotendinous unit and complete loss of function

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First ankle sprain with sport or work disability
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient with fractures, dislocation or hyperlaxity
- Previous ankle sprain
